{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2921876,"name":"","username":"SeanSun6814","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/e36b37/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-01-08T21:53:10.342Z","cooked":"

Hi all,

I am the Controls lead of Team Ellipse (6814) and author of the tutorial series “0 to Autonomous in FRC Java.”

Today I am here to share my robot simulation project. With minimal adjustments to your real-world Java code, you will be able to run it in a 3D simulator powered by the Unity game engine.

image2932×1803 843 KB

Don’t believe it? Download now and try for yourself!

  1. Download Java library and your version of the simulator (and unzip everything)
  2. Run Robot.java (sample robot code) in the Java library
  3. Run Unity simulator executable
  4. Use keyboard to drive the robot

Simulator for Mac
Simulator for Windows

Java library

Left/right shiftkeys: drive robot
Number key “1”: hold to drive backwards
Number key “2”: move elevator
Number key “3”: close intake
Space bar: change camera angle
Esc: exit simulation

Help with opening the simulator in Mac: Link1, Link2

How does this whole system work? Unity uses C#, not Java, right?

  1. My Java library sets up a TCP server on your local computer, and Unity’s TCP client using C# connects to it.
  2. Unity handles all the physics, graphics, and keyboard inputs.
  3. Every update frame, the Unity simulator sends these data through TCP to your Java robot code.
  4. After the Java library runs the robot program using these data, it sends all motor control signals back to Unity using TCP
  5. Unity receives motor signals and applies them to the 3D simulation, then continues to the next update frame

Looking forward, this simulator is far from complete, and I need your help! If you have any suggestions/bugs feedback/questions/potential uses for this sim, please reply below. I will be happy to consider them!

Sean Sun
Controls lead @ 6814
Creator of “0 to Autonomous in FRC Java”

Seems pretty interesting so far, a way to configure the unity controls and controller support would probably be the most useful thing.

Another would be some sort of simulated sensors that the unity game would send back to the code over the same server. Just a left / right encoder, elevator encoder, and drive angle would be great.

I’ve been doing some work with Unity myself. Here is a link to a Google doc with some Info. It uses the WebSockets interface that comes standard with WPILib and is made to tie in directly with the RoboRIO IO. WPILib Simulation Integration with Unity - Google Docs

Here is a link to a brief YouTube video with a demonstration. https://youtu.be/P1K9kcJm_5Q

I’m happy to provide more info if you’re interested. My goal is to create something that can be used across FIRST.

I have a FTC Unity project and I need someone who understand the WPIlib

See our latest project -download the app Downloadable VRS Platform! – Virtual Robot Simulator

What we want @ a High level: Modify the FTC Romi RC App to run a our robot in Unity-running locally.

What we need: someone to convert the FTC RomiRC App to allow websocket communication to our Unity game. The FTC Romi uses the WPILib WebSockets protocol spec. We need someone to write a WebSocket client in Unity to interface with this protocol.

For 10 years I’ve been the director of the FIRST Tech Challenge (FTC) Robotics program in Illinois.

I’ve done an integration of Unity with WPILib Robot code. Take a look at the project here: GitHub - kinahawi/FRC-2021-Starter-Project: Unity project to use when getting started with simulations for FIRST Robotics during the 2021 season..

Here is a previous CD post where I describe what I’ve done and provide links to introductory videos: Tutorial to create simple drivable chassis in Unity

Good Luck!

Bill

I have a FTC Unity project and I need someone who understand the WPIlib

See our latest project -download the app Downloadable VRS Platform! – Virtual Robot Simulator

What we want @ a High level: Modify the FTC Romi RC App to run a our robot in Unity-running locally.

What we need: someone to convert the FTC RomiRC App to allow websocket communication to our Unity game. The FTC Romi uses the WPILib WebSockets protocol spec. We need someone to write a WebSocket client in Unity to interface with this protocol.

For 10 years I’ve been the director of the FIRST Tech Challenge (FTC) Robotics program in Illinois.

Could you tell us how we can import this library to the simulator?
